page.lettertext:
Belgia 28 Maij 1589
An
o
1589 May 28 / touching the Mutiny of
Berg
e
op Soom
and
[my lady] of
Kent
/
S
r
Antony Winckfild wyff
/ and off
Ostende
It may please yo
r
H. immediatly uppon
e writing
of my last
e 15 of this p
nt
, I departed from
e
Hage
for Berghen up Zoome, and heere I have continued these
10 daies, w
t
some other Commissioners w
ch
e
Councell of
state
hath sent hither w
t
me, and to suche purpose, as I
have signified in my former l
re
s. The 22 of this
p
nt
I receaved her
Ma
ties
l
re
of
e 18 and an other from
my
LL.
of
e Councell of
e 13 of
e same: wherto for
answear to her Hig
nes
l
re
, it may please yo
r
L to ad-
vertise, that I was no sooner come hither, but I might pre-
sently perceave,
at
e states of these Provinces have done
a great deale of wrong to
e Governo
r
, Captaines, and
e rest of this Garrison. For though it can not be denied
but
at there are disorders among them, as it can not other
wise choose, where so many live in Garrison, yet
e most
part will be easely remedied, and there are none in
at
degree, in respect of any daunger to
e towne, as her Ma
tie
by their l
re
s hath bin boaren in hand. The division
that was growen between
e Governo
r
and Captens, by
e absence of some
at are in
England,
and by
e pre-
sence and good cariage of
S
r
Francis Vere
, was very muche
appeased, before I came hither: and since I have bin care-
full, to make
e accord more perfitte. And as for all
other disorders, uppon
e first motion of redresse
at I
made unto them, there was not one of them but offered
very willingly to accept of any suche order, as I should
commend unto them. Wheruppon I have caused them
to promise reformac
o
n of most maters complained of
by
e Councell of state, or presented by
e Burgmasters
of
e towne, not being prejudiciall to
e Treaty w
t
her Ma
tie
. The greatest difficultie
at I found, was
to induce
e Cornets of my
L. Willughby
, and
S
r
Willi-
am Russell
to be contented to transport themselves
into
Gueldres
to
S
r
Martin Schincke
, for
e rescue of
Blienbeecke,
wherof I writte in my last to yo
r
L.
and I was earnestly solicited by
e Councell of state
to persuade them unto it. But they doe alleage, that
they are not to folowe
e direction of
e states,
or of
any
other, but of
e L. Generall. Howbeit uppon declara-
tion made, in c
o
ference w
t
them, of
e necessitie of this
present service, and that their being heere is for
e ser-
vice of
e Contrey, as likewise
at in my L. Generals
fol.238v
absence, I did not dout but her Ma
tie
would be pleased
that uppon urgent occasions some part of her forces might
be disposed by
e states of
e Contrey, they have yelded
to goe
e voiage, and to receave S
r
Francis Vere for
their c
o
maunder: wherto I have used some instance to
persuade him, in respect of his good government, for
e
affection w
ch
all
e souldiers beare him, and because he
hath
e office of serjant Major generall. Besides,
S
r
Thomas Morgan
, whose advise in this mater I have used
continually, doth undertake
e defense of
e towne in
their absence, w
t
out requiring any supplie, and hath
also sent unreq
e
sted a choise company of a 150 foote
w
t
them: and all embarked, as this day. I have writ-
ten to S
r
Martin Schincke
at they may be well intreated,
and I have dealt by letter w
t
e Councell of State to doe
e like,
at it may be a beginning of greater good liking
and amitie between us. Moreover because it is uncer-
taine howe long they may be abroade, I have intreated
S
r
Thomas Shirleis
deputy to advance certaine weekes len-
dinges to eche company: wherto he hath bin willing, and
I hope my proceeding in these affaires will stand w
t
her Hig
nes
pleasure. It were too muche to troble yo
r
L. w
t
all suche occasions of offense,
at
e Governo
r
and
Captaines heere might justly conceave against
e states
of
e Contrey. Their owne souldiers in this towne are farre
more dissolute then o
r
s, and for want of paiment and
other good order from them, committ many outrages up-
pon
e bowers of
e contrey, whiche is often reported
to
e reproche of
e Inglishe nation, because
e greater
nomber of
e Garrison doth consist of them. In
effect, I do manifestly finde that
e badde offices,
and undiscret advertisments,
at are given under
hand by their Commissaries and petit officers making
mountaines of molhils, and reporting many thinges
untruly and maliciously, hath given a great occasion
of these misconstructions: and w
t
all
e states owne
gelousie and credulitie is so immoderat in every ma-
ter, as it will hardly permitt any good correspondence
betweene her Ma
tie
and them. The report of their
deputies heere,
at are joined w
t
me in C
o
mission, can
not but occasion a great deale of good, when they
fol.239r
shall returne to
e Councell of state. For they doe plain-
ly see, and c
o
fesse, and promise to testifie, that they were
very muche abused, by wrong informac
o
ns.
Notw
t
standing
at all thinges were sufficiently orde-
red and compounded, before her Hig
nes
letters came
hither: yet
e Governo
r
and I made knowen w
at
her
Ma
tie
had written in all thinges: and I signified a
part to S
r
Thomas Morgan, what offence her Ma
tie
had con-
ceaved against him, for his rashe usage in publishing
her letter written to my L. Willughby. Wherto his answear
is
at he did it very unwillingly, and provoked
unto it by
Cap
t
Salisburies
speeches, who vaunted in
open audience to have as great a part in
e towne as
e Governo
r
: wheruppon for feare of further
mischief,
and greater division among
e souldiers, he thought it
his best course to publishe her Ma
ties
pleasure in that
letter: wheras otherwise he hath alwaies honored my
L Willughby, and doth protest,
at he doth desire, and
will seeke to deserve his favo
r
, w
t
all maner of good
endevo
r
s. Moreover I caused all her Ma
ties
captaines and companies, at severall times, and in
troupes, to take their othe of obedience to S
r
Thomas Mor-
gan as their Governo
r
: w
ch
they did in my presence,
w
t
out any maner of difficultie. And as for
those of
Gertrudenbergh,
at were offensive to
e states,
they are already gone into England, saving my Lady
of Kent, who is heere w
t
some fewe in her familie.
The Councell of state hath sett downe an article in o
r
commission, to cause her to be removed from hens. But
I have travailed w
t
these
at are joined w
t
me, and
they are in part contented, in respect of her sexe, of
her calling, of her present want of mony to furnishe
her homewardes, and for other like causes, not to urge
e mater any further, and yet
e Councell of state
and
S
r
Thomas Morgan
Count Maurice
calle uppon them
for it very instantly. S
r
John Wingfild is
still at
Breda,
detened partly for debt, and partly,
as the Governo
r
there doth write hither, uppon c
o
-
maundem
t
of
e
Duke
: to whome there is a trompet
sent from hens, w
t
letters from my Lady: albeit it is not
yet certainly knowen, whether he be dead or alive.
fol.239v
I have written divers letters to those of
Dort
about
my La.
childe
, to whiche I have receaved no answear
as yet. In my jorney hither, I was divers waies let-
ted for going by
e towne: but I purpose to take it
in my returne. The Escoutette chief justicer of
e
towne hath surceased his sute, uppon my letters, but
e mercer will not yeld: and (to deliver it in secre-
cie to yo
r
L.) I doe suspect
by
at
e communciation w
ch
I have had w
t
my La that
e mercer taketh hold of
some offer
at was made by my La. to
e partener of
e said mercer at Gertrudenbergh, That she should
pawne her child for her debt: whiche my La. doth
confesse unto me
at she offered, but
at it was not
accepted. But whether it be nowe claimed by the
mercer, and
e childe detened uppon pretext of that
offer, I can not understand. It is also told me
at
S
r
John Wingfild himself hath signed a writing sins
his being in prison, by whiche he licenceth his credi-
o
r
s to keepe his child, till his debtes be all dischar-
ged, aswell former, as those he shall make during
the time of his imprisonment. At my being in Dort
I shall knowe
e certaintie of all. In
e meane wh
ile
my La. is farre out of patience, sheading teares co
n-
tinually and lamenting her estate. For mine owne
part, whatsoever I can doe, or devise I will not
faile to practise for her: but in regard of her impa-
tience, it were a great deale better for her, to be in
England then heere, where she hath litle company or
c
o
fort fitte for her Estate. I send yo
r
L. heerw
t
e states answear to
at proposition w
ch
I made unto them in her Ma
ties
name about the
towne of Ostend, wherof I sent
e copie w
t
my last
letter. It seemed by yo
r
letters written unto me
e 1 and 5 of this p
nt
, that her Ma
ties
meaning wa
s
not to w
t
drawe her forces from thens, unles
e
states would refuse to fortifie
e towne, or diffe
r
it. Howbeit by yo
r
L. last of
e 8 of this moneth
whiche I receaved in this towne, it should appeare
that her Hig
nes
resoluc
o
n was not conditionall, but
at
she was purposed to abandon
e towne, unles the
fol.240r
states will receave it presently into their owne charge.
Because it is a mater of special moment, and her Ma
ties
intention doutfull unto me, I trust it will not dislike
her Hig
nes
if I doe attend an other direction, before I
proceede to those peremptorie termes w
t
e states, who,
as by their answear may also appeare, doe thinke them-
selves wronged by those
at made
e report of suche ex-
treme daunger towardes to
e towne. I have
sent an answear to my LL. of
e Councell, as touching
those proofes w
ch
they require from
e generall states
in my L. Willughbies causes: w
ch
, by reason of mine
absence from
e Hage, I can not procure so soddainly:
but I mind w
t
in these two daies to repaire thither,
and to send their answear, immediatly after.
For other occurrences I am not in a place
that will yelde any great mater.
Hoesden
is besieged
by
e Ennemie: but, as they give it out, sufficiently stoa-
red of victual and men to defend it self. There is also
a rumo
r
at this p
nt
,
at
e house of
Hele
in
Bommels
Weert
is besieged. What provision is made for preser-
vation of those places, I shall not learne, till I come to
the Hage. They have lately choisen 10 newe cap-
taines, and given them commmission to Levie so many
companies: but all men are so lothe to serve
e states,
as it will be long before those companies be raised.
and otherwise, leaving their Garrisons furnished, I
can not see
at they can drawe to any service above
3000 in all these Provinces. O
r
Englishe compa-
nies in this towne are indifferent complete, and full of
very able and talle souldiers.
And thus for this pre-
sent I take my leave of yo
r
L. most humbly.
From
e Hage
Berghen
May 28. 89 From Berghen.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
